subject: Hack with the legendary Feross Aboukhadijeh!
content:
Hey guys, my friend Feross, originally from Stanford, famed for getting
1,000,000 users in a few days with ytinstant.com, founder of
https://peercdn.com which got bought by Yahoo, and who has become such a
legendary hacker he's now a quora topic, is working on a fantastic
open-source project and would like nothing more than to find  a great,
really enthusiastic collaborator. He's happy to mentor them. Would you be
willing to help us find him one by thinking of your friends who might be
interested and by emailing out to any relevant lists you know of? Or join
him yourself!

His product's description:
WebTorrent <https://webtorrent.io/> is a torrent client that works in the
browser! YEP, THAT'S RIGHT. THE BROWSER. It's written completely in
JavaScript – the language of the web – and uses WebRTC (data channels) for
true peer-to-peer transport without browser plugins, extensions, or
installations.

Imagine a peer-to-peer YouTube where viewers help to host the site's
content. By making BitTorrent easier to use, we can get more people to
participate and take the first steps to re-decentralizing
<http://redecentralize.org/> the Internet.

You can see WebTorrent in action and use it to send a file to a friend
here: https://instant.io

-- 
Jacob
qoɔɐɾ

jcole@mit.edu
dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
tmad4000@gmail.com
(858) 740-6970
html_content:
Hey guys, my friend Feross, originally from Stanford, famed for getting 1,000,000 users in a few days with ytinstant.com, founder of https://peercdn.com which got bought by Yahoo, and who has become such a legendary hacker he's now a quora topic, is working on a fantastic open-source project and would like nothing more than to find  a great, really enthusiastic collaborator. He's happy to mentor them. Would you be willing to help us find him one by thinking of your friends who might be interested and by emailing out to any relevant lists you know of? Or join him yourself!

His product's description:
WebTorrent is a torrent client that works in the browser! YEP, THAT'S RIGHT. THE BROWSER. It's written completely in JavaScript – the language of the web – and uses WebRTC (data channels) for true peer-to-peer transport without browser plugins, extensions, or installations.

Imagine a peer-to-peer YouTube where viewers help to host the site's content. By making BitTorrent easier to use, we can get more people to participate and take the first steps to re-decentralizing the Internet.

You can see WebTorrent in action and use it to send a file to a friend here: https://instant.io

--
Jacob
qoɔɐɾ

jcole@mit.edu
dev.jacobcole@gmail.com
tmad4000@gmail.com
(858) 740-6970

subject: real-time news data scraping
content:
Hi HackSphere!

We are trying to make a general suggestion engine. One part of this is a
real-time news suggestion & summarization site, what are the good tools /
api to scrape news papers from multiple sites?

This is going in parallel with an idea matching algorithm which suggests
relevant ideas.

Jiannan
html_content:
Hi HackSphere! 

We are trying to make a general suggestion engine. One part of this is a real-time news suggestion & summarization site, what are the good tools / api to scrape news papers from multiple sites?

This is going in parallel with an idea matching algorithm which suggests relevant ideas.

Jiannan

subject: Impromptu hacksphere meetup in SF at the Future of Programming meetup tomorrow
content:
HWant to come to this meet up on the future of programming in San Francisco
at 2 PM at the Mechanics Institute tomorrow?

Hi all, it looks like several of the most awesome people I know are going
to be showing up at the Future of Programming meetup in SF tomorrow at 2 PM
at the Mechanics Institute! Want to turn this into an impromptu hacksphere
SF meet up?
 Mechanic's Institute, 57 Post Street, SF
 I think it will be in a conference room on the third floor, but just ask
the guy at the front desk where the future of programming meet up  is


 for those who don’t know, the future programming meet up is a group of
people who get together roughly every month to go talk about paradigm
shifting ways of have humans can interact with computers. Sometimes we have
talks, sometimes an open discussion. I’m a big fan of two minute lightning
talks  with one  minute of discussion after  given by the people there, as
a way to help facilitate meaningful connections  :-)
html_content:
HWant to come to this meet up on the future of programming in San Francisco at 2 PM at the Mechanics Institute tomorrow?

Hi all, it looks like several of the most awesome people I know are going to be showing up at the Future of Programming meetup in SF tomorrow at 2 PM at the Mechanics Institute! Want to turn this into an impromptu hacksphere SF meet up? 
 Mechanic's Institute, 57 Post Street, SF
 I think it will be in a conference room on the third floor, but just ask the guy at the front desk where the future of programming meet up  is


 for those who don’t know, the future programming meet up is a group of people who get together roughly every month to go talk about paradigm shifting ways of have humans can interact with computers. Sometimes we have talks, sometimes an open discussion. I’m a big fan of two minute lightning talks  with one  minute of discussion after  given by the people there, as a way to help facilitate meaningful connections  :-)

subject: Re: Curiosity
content:
Definitely following this, pretty awesome mission.

If you haven't seen the animation of the landing
sequence<http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BudlaGh1A0o>,
it's worth watching. This is the first time that the "sky crane" landing
mechanism has been tried, and it should be pretty thrilling!

Success is far from guaranteed. Only America has successfully landed
anything on Mars. Russia has tried 9
times<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exploration_of_Mars#Timeline_of_Mars_exploration>,
and 8 of them failed. The one other, Mars 3, was a lander that they heard
back from for just 15 seconds on the surface of Mars before it died.

Yea, the odyssey orbiter had a sticky reaction wheel, which are pretty cool
devices for adjusting attitude on small satellites. We'll still know within
a few hours!

Doug

> will be out of view of earth at the time of the landing, so one of the NASA
> satilites around Mars - Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO) or Odyssey - will
> need to provide a communication relay. Odyssey can provide a live relay at
> 8kb/s, but MRO has a store-and-forward setup, so it will record the landing
> transmissions from MSL, but will only be able to send them on to earth
> after the landing has finished.I believe MRO is in position, but Odyssey
> had an anomaly while trying to alter its orbit to get over the landing
> site. I think they will try again early next week, and will announce on the

html_content:
Definitely following this, pretty awesome mission.

If you haven't seen the animation of the landing sequence, it's worth watching. This is the first time that the "sky crane" landing mechanism has been tried, and it should be pretty thrilling!

Success is far from guaranteed. Only America has successfully landed anything on Mars. Russia has tried 9 times, and 8 of them failed. The one other, Mars 3, was a lander that they heard back from for just 15 seconds on the surface of Mars before it died.

Yea, the odyssey orbiter had a sticky reaction wheel, which are pretty cool devices for adjusting attitude on small satellites. We'll still know within a few hours!

Doug

On Sat, Jul 21, 2012 at 3:32 PM, Matt Vernacchia <vernamatt@gmail.com> wrote:
i'm not working on MSL, so I wont have any "insider info", but ill keep you posted on what I do hear.
The latest news I've heard is regarding communications. The landing site will be out of view of earth at the time of the landing, so one of the NASA satilites around Mars - Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO) or Odyssey - will need to provide a communication relay. Odyssey can provide a live relay at 8kb/s, but MRO has a store-and-forward setup, so it will record the landing transmissions from MSL, but will only be able to send them on to earth after the landing has finished.I believe MRO is in position, but Odyssey had an anomaly while trying to alter its orbit to get over the landing site. I think they will try again early next week, and will announce on the 25th whether they will have live communications for the landing.

subject: Re: Software to help with Software transitions
content:
yeah dude a hotkey trainer for all apps would be invaluable

Shadi Barhoumi
(650) 255 - 7536

On March 17, 2014 at 5:37:19 AM, Rafael Cosman (rafaelc@stanford.edu) wrote:

We all make transitions in the software that we use. It might be useful to have a tool for making these transitions smoother.

I’ve recently moved from Sublime to Atom, but I still often open Sublime by accident. Just out of habit, or because an extensions is still associated with Sublime. I don’t want to remove Sublime from my system (because I expect I may still need it in the future, and it’s still a great piece of software that I’m proud to have) but I want help remembering to use Atom instead of Sublime. Because I’ve made a conscious decision to make this switch, my computer should help me.

Imagine a simple application where I select “Transition from [Sublime] -> [Atom]” (those are drop down menus) and then it will help me to use Atom whenever I would have otherwise used Sublime. Like whenever Sublime would open, instead this application makes a popup saying 

“Are you sure you want to open this file in Sublime? Atom may be a better choice”
buttons: [Use Sublime]   [Use Atom]

Rev2 of this software will train you to use the new hotkeys whenever you try to use the old ones. Thankfully with Atom/Sublime the hotkeys are almost identical.



— Rafa

Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858
Rafael's Schedule

content:
Boom! Specifying arbitrary intentions to your computer. This could be like If This Than That but it would work locally on your own machine.


Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858
Rafael's Schedule

From: H. Lee howonlee@stanford.edu
Reply: hacksphere@googlegroups.com hacksphere@googlegroups.com
Date: March 17, 2014 at 8:40:23 AM
To: hacksphere@googlegroups.com hacksphere@googlegroups.com
Subject:  Re: Software to help with Software transitions  

Let's try the Lally paper.

Best Regards,
Howon Lee


On Mon, Mar 17, 2014 at 8:34 AM, H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
This is a concrete instance of the abstract problem of habit change.

The literature has the most general method of habit change, due to Gollwitzer. It's called an implementation intention, and it's pretty ridiculous:

Say,

"If ___ (condition),

I will ____ (action)"

A concrete example comes from one of Gollwitzer's experiment with heroin addicts. If you ask a heroin addict to compose a CV for you, they have a success rate at doing this of about 0 percent. If you ask them to say, "If ___ (a condition that involves a specific time and place), I will write the CV", lots of them did. Gollwitzer apparently habitually promotes this thing, but here it is: http://www.psych.nyu.edu/gollwitzer/01BrandLengGoll_ActInit.pdf

If you think it's ridiculous, you should just try it. The caveat is those sample sizes!

I've studied this at some length, actually, so you can ask questions. Probably another interesting point is the regressions that Phillipa Lally did for how long it takes to form a habit: 15 to 250 days (250 days is an extrapolation, the study lasted 84 days). Most her papers are pretty cool (http://www.ucl.ac.uk/hbrc/diet/lallyp.html). This is How are habits formed: Modelling habit formation in the real world. That paper, I don't have any annoying methodological problems with, but I did a "ooh, cool charts!" reading of that one. I'm not sure about how to get it without journal access, so if you're interested in reading it for yourself, you should reply back or something. (I dunno: are attachments possible for Google Groups?)

There's an interesting piece of misinformation floating around about how it takes 21 days. Actual experience should tell you that's a load of crock, but the source of the factoid is interesting. A plastic surgeon named Maxwell Maltz noticed that his patients recovered from the self-image difference from plastic surgery about 21 days after the surgery, and talked to other surgeons about it, getting a bunch of anecdotal evidence that people generally do that for non-plastic surgeries as well. He also did the reading on Norbert Weiner's cybernetics, and therefore concluded that the self-image was a self-regulatory process a la cybernetics. Reasonable, but the timeframe for the habit was fairly off.

The other interesting part about Maltz is that he started promulgating this idea that visualization has this modality of action where it will do everything for you. Actually, he gives a lot of examples of visualization being excellent fake practice, for which there's a lot of good evidence. So The Secret and other scummy books like it are intellectual heritors of this book.

Probably the best individual book for actually reading about habit change is Baumeister's Willpower, it's a good lay reading. The less lay reading is The Handbook of Self-Regulation, edited by Baumeister and co. You can find that on the internet fairly easily.

(this is what I do instead of studying for finals...)

Best Regards,
Howon Lee

html_content:
This is a concrete instance of the abstract problem of habit change.

The literature has the most general method of habit change, due to Gollwitzer. It's called an implementation intention, and it's pretty ridiculous:

Say,

"If ___ (condition),

I will ____ (action)"

A concrete example comes from one of Gollwitzer's experiment with heroin addicts. If you ask a heroin addict to compose a CV for you, they have a success rate at doing this of about 0 percent. If you ask them to say, "If ___ (a condition that involves a specific time and place), I will write the CV", lots of them did. Gollwitzer apparently habitually promotes this thing, but here it is: http://www.psych.nyu.edu/gollwitzer/01BrandLengGoll_ActInit.pdf

If you think it's ridiculous, you should just try it. The caveat is those sample sizes!

I've studied this at some length, actually, so you can ask questions. Probably another interesting point is the regressions that Phillipa Lally did for how long it takes to form a habit: 15 to 250 days (250 days is an extrapolation, the study lasted 84 days). Most her papers are pretty cool (http://www.ucl.ac.uk/hbrc/diet/lallyp.html). This is How are habits formed: Modelling habit formation in the real world. That paper, I don't have any annoying methodological problems with, but I did a "ooh, cool charts!" reading of that one. I'm not sure about how to get it without journal access, so if you're interested in reading it for yourself, you should reply back or something. (I dunno: are attachments possible for Google Groups?)

There's an interesting piece of misinformation floating around about how it takes 21 days. Actual experience should tell you that's a load of crock, but the source of the factoid is interesting. A plastic surgeon named Maxwell Maltz noticed that his patients recovered from the self-image difference from plastic surgery about 21 days after the surgery, and talked to other surgeons about it, getting a bunch of anecdotal evidence that people generally do that for non-plastic surgeries as well. He also did the reading on Norbert Weiner's cybernetics, and therefore concluded that the self-image was a self-regulatory process a la cybernetics. Reasonable, but the timeframe for the habit was fairly off.

The other interesting part about Maltz is that he started promulgating this idea that visualization has this modality of action where it will do everything for you. Actually, he gives a lot of examples of visualization being excellent fake practice, for which there's a lot of good evidence. So The Secret and other scummy books like it are intellectual heritors of this book.

Probably the best individual book for actually reading about habit change is Baumeister's Willpower, it's a good lay reading. The less lay reading is The Handbook of Self-Regulation, edited by Baumeister and co. You can find that on the internet fairly easily.

(this is what I do instead of studying for finals...)

Best Regards,
Howon Lee


On Mon, Mar 17, 2014 at 5:37 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
We all make transitions in the software that we use. It might be useful to have a tool for making these transitions smoother.

I’ve recently moved from Sublime to Atom, but I still often open Sublime by accident. Just out of habit, or because an extensions is still associated with Sublime. I don’t want to remove Sublime from my system (because I expect I may still need it in the future, and it’s still a great piece of software that I’m proud to have) but I want help remembering to use Atom instead of Sublime. Because I’ve made a conscious decision to make this switch, my computer should help me.

Imagine a simple application where I select “Transition from [Sublime] -> [Atom]” (those are drop down menus) and then it will help me to use Atom whenever I would have otherwise used Sublime. Like whenever Sublime would open, instead this application makes a popup saying 

“Are you sure you want to open this file in Sublime? Atom may be a better choice”
buttons: [Use Sublime]   [Use Atom]

Rev2 of this software will train you to use the new hotkeys whenever you try to use the old ones. Thankfully with Atom/Sublime the hotkeys are almost identical.



— Rafa

subject: Re: Google Keep
content:
I use OneNote for everything.  I just started on a tablet PC back in 2008 and have never looked around at something else.

It works well, though is a huge disk hog.

Sent from my iPhone

On Apr 19, 2014, at 6:33 PM, "Neil Satra" <neil.satra@gmail.com<mailto:neil.satra@gmail.com>> wrote:

Integration is off to a good start, with quick note-taking ability on Android, and everything being synced across devices through Google Drive, thus giving a nice, consistent web interface to it too. Personally, I've switched over from using crappy Evernote everywhere to OneNote on the Surface Pro and Keep on my phone.

I haven't seen any numbers on traction.


On Sun, Apr 20, 2014 at 2:10 AM, Michael Plasmeier <plaz@theplaz.com<mailto:plaz@theplaz.com>> wrote:
I wonder if this is gaining traction?

Its >1 year old, but it is not well integrated with other Google properties, making it fairly orphaned.

Does anyone know?

I haven't seen any numbers on traction.
